content.text: Calculate the distance travelled by the cyclist in section P from time \(= 0\) to time \(= 100\mathrm{s}\)
distance travelled =   .........  m
Describe the motion of the cyclist in each of sections Q, R and S shown in Fig. 1.1
Q
R
S
The cyclist is moving north along the road
Determine the velocity of the cyclist at time \(= 300 \text{s}\). Include the unit
velocity of cyclist =
A cyclist is travelling along a straight road. Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graph for the cyclist. The graph is divided into four sections labelled P, Q, R and S
The weight of the concrete beam is 1540N
Calculate the pressure on the ground due to the concrete beam
pressure =   .........  N/cm²
A builder starts to raise one end of the beam
He uses a force of \(1030\mathrm{N}\) at a perpendicular distance of \(120\mathrm{cm}\) from the pivot. Fig. 2.2 shows the arrangement
Calculate the moment of the \(1030\mathrm{N}\) force about the pivot
moment =   .........  Ncm
Describe how the builder can use a smaller force to lift the beam
The builder positions the beam as shown in Fig. 2.3
State why the beam shown in Fig. 2.3 is less stable than the beam shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1 shows a concrete beam resting on the ground
Statements A–F describe the main stages in the transfer of energy from the Sun to electrical energy in a wind turbine generator
The statements A–F are not in the correct order
A Air moves from regions of high pressure to regions of low pressure
B The turbine blades turn a generator
C Energy from the Sun heats the atmosphere unevenly
D Uneven heating of the atmosphere produces regions of different atmospheric pressure
E The generator produces electrical energy
F Moving air turns the turbine blades
Complete the flow chart to describe how a wind turbine uses energy from the Sun to generate electrical energy. Insert the missing letters in the empty boxes
State two disadvantages, apart from cost, of using wind turbines to produce electrical energy for homes and industry
Electricity is distributed from wind turbines to homes and industry
The motor exerts a force of \(25 \text{N}\) on the load. It lifts the load a vertical distance of \(2.0 \text{m}\)
Calculate the work done by the motor on the load
work done on the load =   .........  J
State the useful energy output of the electric motor when it lifts the load 2.0 m
useful energy output =   .........  J
The useful energy output of the motor is less than the energy input to the motor
Explain why the useful energy output is less than the energy input
The student uses the motor to lift a different load. The motor does 80 J of work when it lifts this load. It takes 5.0 s to lift the load
Calculate the power output of the electric motor
power output =   .........  W
A student uses an electric motor to lift a load. Fig. 4.1 shows the arrangement
Describe how the particles in Fig. 5.1 exert a pressure on the walls of the box
The number of gas particles in the box increases. The temperature of the gas does not change
State and explain the effect, if any, on the pressure exerted by the gas particles on the walls of the box
Fig. 5.1 represents some particles of a gas in a metal box. The arrows represent the directions of movement of the particles
(not to scale)
The student measures the wavelength of the waves by measuring the distance between one peak and the next peak
Describe a more accurate method for determining the wavelength
The wavelength of the waves is \(4.0 \text{cm}\) and their frequency is \(6.0 \text{Hz}\)
Calculate the wave speed
wave speed =   .........  cm/s
Fig. 6.1 shows water waves in the tank travelling from deep water to shallow water
State and explain what happens to the waves as they move from deep water to shallow water
name of effect
explanation
A student observes waves on the surface of water in a tank. The waves all have the same wavelength
On Fig. 7.1, continue the path of each ray beyond the lens as far as the screen
Visible light is a region of the electromagnetic spectrum
State **one** region of the electromagnetic spectrum which has waves of longer wavelength than waves of visible light
Describe **one** use of gamma rays
Describe **one** harmful effect on people of excessive exposure to gamma rays
Gamma rays are another region of the electromagnetic spectrum
Fig. 7.1 represents two rays of light striking a thin converging lens. The rays are both parallel to the principal axis
F<sub>2</sub> and F<sub>1</sub> are the focal points of the lens
On Fig. 8.1, label both the poles on each magnet
Describe how to plot the shape and direction of the magnetic field pattern shown in Fig. 8.1
Fig. 8.1 shows the magnetic field pattern around two permanent magnets. The magnets are repelling each other
State the name of two other components in the circuit
The current in the lamp is 0.40A. The potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp is 6.0V
Calculate the power dissipated in the lamp
Draw on Fig. 9.1 to show a lamp connected in parallel with the lamp in the circuit. Use the correct symbol
Fig. 9.1 shows a series circuit. Two of the components in the circuit are labelled
When the magnet moves towards the coil of wire, the pointer on the sensitive voltmeter deflects to the right
Explain why the pointer deflects
State two changes that increase the deflection on the sensitive voltmeter
Fig. 10.1 shows an arrangement used to demonstrate electromagnetic induction
Fig. 10.2 shows the symbol for a transformer. The primary coil is connected to a voltage of 180 V a.c
Table 11.1 gives information about the particles shown in Fig. 11.1
Using the information in Fig. 11.1, write in the empty boxes to complete Table 11.1

table.html:
name of particlenumber of particlesposition of particlerelative charge of particle
electron
neutronin the nucleus
6+1 (plus one)

content.text: A museum displays an item made of ancient wood. When the wood was new, the item contained \(8.00 \text{mg}\) of the isotope shown in Fig. 11.1. The item now contains \(2.00 \text{mg}\) of the isotope. The half-life of the isotope is 5700 years
Calculate the age of the wood in the item
age of wood =   .........  years
Fig. 11.1 represents all the particles in an atom which is a radioactive isotope of carbon
Fig. 12.1 represents the Earth and the Sun at one point in the Earth's orbit of the Sun
Explain the apparent daily motion of the Sun across the sky
List the four planets closest to the Sun in order of their distance from the Sun. One is done for you
The Sun mostly consists of two elements
State the two elements
The Sun is a star in a galaxy
State the name of the galaxy
